@hholst80 btw, the issue with select grad is that it seems to do "0*branch1+branch2", which has unwanted effect of turning into nan when branch1 is inf. Here's a simpler way to show this problem -- the result is NaN even though problematic branch is not selected.

@yuanbyu may know if there's any potential way to remedy this problem. Maybe if select gradient used select instead of multiplication by 0?

x = tf.Variable(0.0)
f = tf.select(False, tf.log(x), 0)
g, = tf.gradients(f, [x])
sess = tf.InteractiveSession()
x.initializer.run()
g.eval()
Out[0]: nan

body:
@hholst80 btw, the issue with select grad is that it seems to do "0*branch1+branch2", which has unwanted effect of turning into `nan` when `branch1` is `inf`. Here's a simpler way to show this problem -- the result is `NaN` even though problematic branch is not selected.

@yuanbyu may know if there's any potential way to remedy this problem. Maybe if `select` gradient used `select` instead of multiplication by 0?

```
x = tf.Variable(0.0)
f = tf.select(False, tf.log(x), 0)
g, = tf.gradients(f, [x])
sess = tf.InteractiveSession()
x.initializer.run()
g.eval()
Out[0]: nan
```
